Mechanistic insight into the photocatalytic N-alkylation of piperazine with alcohols over TiO2 supported Pd catalysts Weikun Chen Investigation Formal analysis Writing – original draft Xiao Fu Investigation Formal analysis Xiaoying Liu Investigation Formal analysis Linmin Ye Investigation Formal analysis Youzhu Yuan Supervision Writing – review & editing ⁎ State Key Laboratory of Physical Chemistry of Solid Surfaces, National Engineering Laboratory for Green Chemical Productions of Alcohols–Ethers–Esters, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Xiamen University, Xiamen 361005, China State Key Laboratory of Physical Chemistry of Solid Surfaces, National Engineering Laboratory for Green Chemical Productions of Alcohols–Ethers–Esters, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Xiamen University Xiamen 361005 China State Key Laboratory of Physical Chemistry of Solid Surfaces, National Engineering Laboratory for Green Chemical Productions of Alcohols–Ethers–Esters, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Xiamen University, Xiamen 361005, China ⁎ Corresponding author. N-alkylated piperazines can be synthesized by the thermal catalytic alkylation of piperazine with alkyl halides or alcohols in the presence of supported metal catalysts. However, these processes either discharge large amounts of waste or require harsh conditions. Here, we report the results of N-alkylation of piperazine with lower alcohols (methanol, ethanol, and propanol) without external hydrogen addition at room temperature in the presence of a TiO2-supported Pd catalyst (Pd/TiO2-P) prepared by photodeposition method. Compared with the catalysts prepared by the conventional chemical reduction or hydrogen reduction, the Pd/TiO2-P catalyst showed the highest conversion of piperazine and the best selectivity to N-alkypiperazines. The mechanistic studies indicated that this phenomenon occurs via tandem photocatalytic reactions involving alcohol dehydrgenation to aldehyde, aldehyde condensation with piperazine to enamine, and enamine hydrogenation to N-alkylated piperazines. Considering the experimental results of methanol isotope kinetics, the α-C–H cleavage of methanol to form hydroxymethyl radical (·CH2OH) was proven to be the rate-determining step in the N-alkylation reaction of piperazine with low carbon alcohols. The characterization and control experiments revealed that the size of Pd nanoparticles and the valence of Pd species were vital to the reaction. The Pd/TiO2-P catalyst with an average of 2.5 ± 0.5 nm Pd particles and approximately 68% Pd0 species on surfaces presented the highest activity for the photocatalytic tandem reactions of methanol dehydrogenation and enamine hydrogenation. Graphic abstract The photocatalytic N-alkylation of piperazine with alcohols has been studied in-depth over Pd/TiO2 catalyst fabricated via photodeposition. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Pd/TiO2 Photocatalysis Piperazine N-alkylation Reaction mechanism Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The development of more green and sustainable N-alkylation routes for functionalizing amines is essential due to the widespread applications of amines and its alkylated derivatives. In various strategies for catalytic N-alkylation reactions, carbonyl compounds and alkyl halides are the most widely used alkylating reagents [1,2]. However, in these cases, when alkyl halides are used, an equal molar amount of halide salts is produced as the reaction proceeds. When carbonyl compounds are used, H2 is required as the reducing agent. Compared with the traditional methods, the direct N-alkylation of amines with alcohols via borrowing hydrogen mechanism can provide an alternative approach without generating any toxic waste and without requiring an external H2 supply [3,4]. This allows the route in which alcohols are used as the alkylation agents to achieve high atomic efficiency in an environmentally friendly manner, with water as the sole by-product. A typical reaction for the N-alkylation of amines with alcohols via the borrowing hydrogen mechanism involves three consecutive steps: (i) the dehydrogenation of an alcohol to aldehyde and H atom bonding with metal (metal-H species); (ii) the dehydration condensation of amines with the formed aldehyde to produce imines; and (iii) the imine hydrogenated by metal-H species to yield the N-alkylated product [5,6]. In the terms of thermal catalysis, harsh reaction conditions (120 °C–200 °C) are usually necessary [7,8]. Moreover, excess amounts of inorganic bases are required to promote alcohol dehydrogenation, which will cause corrosion to the reaction vessel and produce salt waste [9]. Thus, developing more efficient and green catalytic routes for the N-alkylation of amines remains challenging. In recent years, the coupled photoredox reaction has been proven as a promising route for the synthesis of value-added N-alkylated organics [10]. Photocatalytic N-alkylation via borrowing hydrogen can be triggered under mild conditions and has therefore been extensively explored. For instance, homogeneous transition-metal catalysts, such as Ru [11] and Ir [12] have displayed good activity for light-driven N-alkylation of amines with alcohols, but the drawback in the separation of catalyst and product limits their practical application. Meanwhile, metal/semiconductor hybrids, such as Pd/TiO2 [13], Ag/TiO2 [14], and Pd/ZnIn2S4 [15] have also been applied successfully for photocatalytic N-alkylation reactions. In those cases, the N-alkylation involves alcohol photocatalytic dehydrogenation over a semiconductor in tandem with the metal-catalyzed hydrogenation. The studies mainly focused on the N-alkylation of aromatic and primary amines [13–15], and the imine hydrogenation was proposed as the rate-determining reaction [13]. However, investigations on the photocatalytic N-alkylation of N-heterocyclic compounds, such as piperazine, are rare; the relevant catalytic mechanism remains unknown [16]. Piperazine is an important N-heterocyclic compound, and its alkylated derivatives are a vital class of building block for synthesis of antibiotics and antibacterial agents [17,18]. N-alkylation reactions of piperazine with alcohols typically require temperatures exceeding 150 °C [19,20]. In this work, a photodeposition method was adopted to prepare Pd nanoparticles (NPs) onto commercially available TiO2 (Pd/TiO2-P). The resultant Pd/TiO2 catalysts are active in the photocatalytic borrowing hydrogen N-alkylation of piperazine at room temperature (Scheme 1 ). Compared with the chemical reduction by NaBH4 (Pd/TiO2-C) and the hydrogen reduction (Pd/TiO2-H), the photodeposition method endowed the as-prepared Pd/TiO2-P with Pd NPs containing high proportion of Pd0 species, which facilitated the photocatalytic dehydrogenation of alcohols and subsequent hydrogenation reaction. Each step of this tandem process was studied. The α-C–H bond cleavage of methanol was the rate-determining step in the overall N-alkylation of piperazine by isotopic experiments using deuterium-substituted methanol. This work provided an in-depth understanding of N-alkylation of N-heterocyclic compounds. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Preparation of the catalysts 2.1.1 Photodeposition method Different metals were loaded onto the support by photodeposition according to the procedure in literature [21]. Taking the preparation of 1.0Pd/TiO2-P as an example, 0.1 g of commercially available TiO2 (Degussa P25) was firstly dispersed in a 20% methanol aqueous solution, an appropriate amount of PdCl2 solution was added to the suspension after sonication. After the suspension was purged with Ar to eliminate the dissolved oxygen and stirred for 1 h, the solution was irradiated under a 500 W Xe lamp (λ > 300 nm) in Ar atmosphere for another 1 h. The precipitate was filtered for collection using deionized water until Cl– was no longer detected in the filtrate. Then, the precipitate was dried at 60 °C overnight under vacuum in an oven. The obtained solid was denoted as xPd/TiO2-P, with x representing the amount of Pd. CdS and C3N4 were synthesized by using the method found in published literature [22,23], and ZnO was purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. 2.1.2 Chemical reduction method TiO2 (0.1 g) was dispersed in 50 mL water containing PdCl2. After stirring for 1 h, 10 mL of aqueous solution (0.5 M NaBH4) was added dropwise under vigorous stirring. The precipitate was filtered and dried by the same procedure after stirring for 1 h more. The obtained solid was denoted as 1.0Pd/TiO2-C. 2.1.3 Hydrogen reduction method TiO2 (0.5 g) was dispersed in 50 mL of acetone containing Pd(acac)2 by ultrasonication. After stirring for 1 h, the suspension was heated at 70 °C to remove the solvent. The precursor was calcinated at 300 °C for 2 h in air. This was followed by reduction at 300 °C for another 2 h in 5% H2/Ar atmosphere. The obtained solid was denoted as 1.0Pd/TiO2-H. 2.2 Material characterization X-ray diffraction analysis (XRD) was executed using an X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku Ultima IV) equipped with Cu–Kα radiation (40 kV and 30 mA) at 10°/min. The actual content of Pd in the catalyst was tested by inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) on an Agilent ICP-MS 4500 instrument. N2 physisorption was carried out using Micromeritics TriStar II 3020, and the surface areas of the catalysts were determined by using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller method. High-angle annular dark field imaging scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) was used to observe Pd particles on an electron microscope (Phillips Analytical FEI TECNAI F20) with a 200 kV electron acceleration voltage. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted using a PHI QUANTUM 2000 Scanning ESCA Microprobe instrument equipped with an Al-Kα radiation source (hν = 1486.6 eV). Ultraviolet–visible (UV–vis) adsorption spectra were obtained on a Varian Cary 5000 spectrophotometer equipped with a diffuse reflectance accessory. The spectra were collected by using BaSO4 as the reference. Electron spin resonance (ESR) spectroscopy was measured to the analysis of radicals using a Bruker EMX-10/12 ESR spectrometer operating at the X-band frequency, and 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline-N-oxide (DMPO) was used as the radical spin-trapping agent. For in situ ESR measurements, catalyst (10 mg) was dispersed in 5 mL of methanol by ultrasonic treatment. Then, 50 μL of DMPO was added to the suspension. The spectra were recorded after the suspension was illuminated for 5 min under a 500 W Xenon lamp. For low temperature (–173 °C) ESR characterization, 100 mg powder samples in a quartz tube was operated at the X-band frequency of 9.47 GHz and 100 kHz field modulation. Photoluminescence (PL) spectra were performed at ambient temperature over F4500 fluorescence spectrophotometer at an excitation wavelength of 315 nm. 2.3 Catalytic activity test 2.3.1 Photocatalytic N-alkylation reaction Photocatalytic N-alkylation reaction was conducted in a quartz tube reactor with an interlayer for circulating water. Typically, 10 mg of catalyst was ultrasonically dispersed in 5 mL methanol solution containing 0.25 mmol substrate. Then, the reactor was purged with Ar to eliminate the dissolved oxygen. The reaction temperature was controlled by circulating water and stirring for 30 min prior to irradiation to reach adsorption equilibrium. A 500 W Xenon lamp was the light source. After the reaction, the resulting solution was recovered and analyzed by using a gas chromatograph (Agilent 7890A) equipped with a DM-35 amine column and a flame ionization detector. The gaseous products were analyzed using a gas chromatograph (INFICON Micro GC Fusion) equipped with a molecular sieve 5A column and a high-sensitivity thermal conductivity detector. The liquid products of methanol photocatalytic dehydrogenation were analyzed using a high-performance liquid chromatograph (Shimazu LC-20A) equipped with a Shodex SUGAR SH-1011 column by using a 5 mmol/L H2SO4 solution as the mobile phase. For the recycling test, the spent catalyst was centrifuged and washed with methanol five times. Subsequently, the recovered catalyst was reused without drying by using the same procedure. 2.3.2 Condensation of piperazine with formaldehyde Formaldehyde (0.25 mmol) was added to 5 mL methanol containing 0.25 mmol piperazine and 10 mg catalyst under stirring. After the Ar purge, the reactor was sealed and stirred at 25 °C. 2.3.3 Hydrogenation of enamine Homemade enamine was used as an intermediate. This was prepared through the condensation of piperazine with formaldehyde. Pd/TiO2 catalysts (10 mg) were suspended in a 5 mL methanol solution containing 0.25 mmol enamine within an interlayer for circulating water. H2 was purged through the solution for 5 min after the catalyst was dispersed by ultrasonication. The H2 pressure was maintained at atmospheric pressure. The reaction temperature was controlled by circulating water with magnetic stirring at 25 °C. 2.3.4 Kinetic isotope effect experiment The 1.0 Pd/TiO2-P catalysts (10 mg) were suspended in a 5 mL CH3CN solution containing 3.75 mmol CH3OH within an interlayer of circulating water. Ar was purged through the solution for 5 min after the dispersal of the catalyst by ultrasonication. The reaction temperature was controlled by circulating water with magnetic stirring at 25 °C. The procedure of N-methylation was similar to the above except for the addition of 0.25 mmol piperazine. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Evaluation of catalytic performance The N-methylation of piperazine in methanol solution by borrowing hydrogen process was investigated as a benchmark reaction at room temperature, and the results are listed in Table 1 . No product was detected without photocatalyst or photoirradiation (entries 1 and 2). Pd catalysts supported on different semiconductors were evaluated first. Among them, 1.0Pd/TiO2-P prepared by photodeposition showed the best N-methylation activity with 25.9% conversion of piperazine and a relatively high selectivity of 1-methylpiperazine (A) (88.2%) (entry 7). Except for the main product A, an unhydrogenated intermediate 1-methyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydropyrazine (C, 10.9% selectivity) and trace amounts of 1,4-dimethylpiperazine (B, 0.9% selectivity) were present in the organic product. Moreover, hydrogen was formed during the reaction. In addition to TiO2, other supports were also examined for comparison (entries 3−5). The 1.0Pd/CdS-P exhibited low piperazine conversion and poor selectivity of A. The 1.0Pd/C3N4-P and 1.0Pd/ZnO-P were also ineffective, despite showing moderate selectivity of A (68.7% and 50.2%), respectively. Then, the effect of the metal species loaded on TiO2 was explored. Bare TiO2 without metal loading exhibited low conversion and no A was detected (entry 6). The photocatalytic activities of the catalysts increased after metal loading. Noble metal-modified catalysts exhibited higher piperazine conversion (entries 7–9). However, C was the main product of 1.0Pt/TiO2-P and 1.0Au/TiO2-P catalysts. This product may be related to H atoms and the C desorbed readily from the surface of Pt and Au NPs [24]. Thus, more H2 were detected at 1.0Pt/TiO2-P and 1.0Au/TiO2-P. When the non-precious metal Ni and Cu were loaded onto TiO2, the conversion of piperazine improved, but A was scarcely produced. It was remarkable that only Pd decorated on TiO2 catalyst showed the promising activity of N-methylation of piperazine, whereas other metals or semiconductors were inferior. Afterward, the catalytic performances of Pd/TiO2 catalysts prepared by different methods were compared. Although 1.0Pd/TiO2-C prepared by chemical reduction showed 89.1% selectivity to A, the conversion of piperazine was lower (20.1%) compared with that over 1.0Pd/TiO2-P (entry 12). The 1.0Pd/TiO2-H (entry 13) prepared by hydrogen reduction exhibited a similar conversion (24.7%), but its selectivity to N-alkylating product was 71.3%. These results implied that the combination of Pd entity and TiO2 support played a critical role in the N-methylation of piperazine. With this result, the effect of different Pd contents on the N-methylation of piperazine was further explored, and the results are shown in Fig. 1 a. The conversion of piperazine increased from 16.5% to 25.9% when Pd loading increased from 0.5 wt% to 1.0 wt%. When Pd loading was further increased to 5.0 wt%, piperazine conversion began to decrease. However, with increasing Pd loading, the selectivity of A increased from 63.1% to 97.3%, and a trace amount of B appeared when the Pd loading reached 1.0 wt%. In addition, the amount of hydrogen detected continued to decrease, indicating the enhanced hydrogenation capacity of the xPd/TiO2-P catalysts. Fig. 1 b shows the N-methylation of piperazine over the 1.0Pd/TiO2-P catalyst as a function of reaction time. With progressing reaction time, the piperazine conversion increased continuously. It reached 97.9% after 12 h. The amount of hydrogen accumulated continuously. The selectivity to A reached 88.2% at 2 h and then decreased slightly, because A could be further methylated with methanol to form B. However, when the piperazine conversion was 97.9% after 12 h, the selectivity to A was 81.1%. 3.2 Characterization of Pd/TiO2 catalysts Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns of Pd/TiO2 catalysts prepared by different methods. Support TiO2 was composed of both anatase and rutile crystals. Little change was observed in the relative intensity and crystallite size of TiO2 after Pd loading. Clearly, the diffraction peak around 40.2° due to Pd(111) could not be detected when the Pd loading weight was lower than 5.0 wt%, which indicates that the average size of Pd NPs was less than 3.0 nm in these cases. As the Pd content increased to 5.0 wt%, the diffraction line attributed to Pd(111) appeared, indicating the growth of Pd NPs. In addition, elevated Pd content led to a slight decrease in the specific surface area of the Pd/TiO2 catalysts (Table S1). Other control catalysts were also explored by XRD analysis (Fig. S1). No obvious Pd(111) peak was observed in any of these control catalysts due to low metal loading. The morphology of the typical catalyst 1.0Pd/TiO2-P was studied by SEM and TEM. As shown in Fig. S2, the size of TiO2 particle was approximately 20 nm. The TEM and HAADF-STEM images of Pd/TiO2 catalysts revealed that the Pd species were successfully deposited onto the TiO2 (Figs. 3 , S2, and S3). The Pd species of 1.0Pd/TiO2-P and 1.0Pd/TiO2-H were highly dispersed as clusters or NPs with mean diameters of 2.5 and 2.1 nm, respectively (Fig. 3). The 1.0Pd/TiO2-C catalyst showed wide particle size distribution and larger particle size of Pd (3.7 nm). The Pd NPs of xPd/TiO2-P enlarged and aggregated with increasing Pd content (Fig. S3). The change in Pd NPs with elevated Pd content was consistent with the XRD results. The information of composition and valence of the Pd species on the TiO2 surface was investigated by XPS, and the results are shown in Figs. 4 and S4. The area ratio of Pd 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 peak was fixed at 3:2, and the full-width half-maximum (FWHM) was fixed at around 1.9. The XPS binding energy distance between Pd 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 was controlled at around 5.3. Detailed information of the binding energy of the Pd species is listed in Table S2 [25,26]. The proportion of Pd0 in total Pd species for 1.0Pd/TiO2-H (53.3%) was lower than those for 1.0Pd/TiO2-P (66.7%) and 1.0Pd/TiO2-C (68.4%). In addition, the percentage of Pd0 species increased from 43.6% to 66.7% as Pd content increased from 0.5 wt% to 1.0 wt%. Little change in proportion of Pd0 species was observed as Pd content further increased to 5.0 wt%. ESR was used to elucidate the difference in nature of the defect types of 1.0Pd/TiO2 prepared with different methods (Fig. S5). The resonance features observed are attributed to Ti3+ sites that are surface exposed (g = 1.927), to Ti3+ sites that are lattice embedded (g = 1.981) and oxygen vacancies (g = 2.003) [27,28]. The ESR signals of 1.0Pd/TiO2-P and 1.0Pd/TiO2-C were similar to that of TiO2, whereas that of 1.0Pd/TiO2-H was stronger than that of TiO2. The ESR result suggested that hydrogen treatment resulted in more defects. 3.3 Photocatalysis of piperazine N-methylation The photocatalytic N-methylation of piperazine with methanol over Pd/TiO2 proceeded through a tandem mode. Thus, the effect of Pd loading in the respective reaction steps for N-methylation of piperazine was explored to clarify the reasons for the differences in activity among various Pd/TiO2 catalysts. Photocatalytic oxidative dehydrogenation of methanol by respective catalysts was first studied in the absence of piperazine in methanol. As shown in Fig. 5 , no products were formed in the absence of a photocatalyst. A significant increase was found in photocatalytic activity after Pd loading comparing with bare TiO2. The enhancement of photocatalytic activity was attributed to the Schottky barrier formed by metal/semiconductor heterojunction to enhance the charge separation between photogenerated h+ and e– [29]. A small amount of ethylene glycol was formed during methanol dehydrogenation; this was derived from the photocatalytic coupling of formaldehyde and methanol [30]. When metal NPs are used as a cocatalyst, the smaller particle size and metallic state showed better promotion effect on the photocatalytic activity [31,32]. The 1.0Pd/TiO2-H catalyst had lower Pd0 content than 1.0Pd/TiO2-P and 1.0Pd/TiO2-C, but it had better photocatalytic activity than 1.0Pd/TiO2-C (Fig. 5). This phenomenon might be due to the smaller size of Pd NPs and the higher number of defects induced by hydrogen reduction, which was also beneficial for enhancing photocatalytic activity [33]. The 1.0Pd/TiO2-C prepared by NaBH4 had a similar Pd0 content to that of 1.0Pd/TiO2-P, but the Pd NPs were larger and showed less photocatalytic activity. For xPd/TiO2-P catalysts, the photocatalytic activity decreased when Pd loading exceeded 1.0 wt% (Fig. S6). This was attributed to the fact that excessive Pd species deposited on the surface of TiO2 became the recombination centers of the photogenerated h+ and e– [34]. Results of methanol photocatalytic dehydrogenation showed that the trend in the conversion of piperazine from different catalysts was in accordance with their photocatalytic activity. The condensation of piperazine with aldehyde was the next step in N-methylation. Figs. 6 and S7 show the rapid condensation of piperazine with formaldehyde to produce C in 0.2 h even in the absence of the catalyst. The consumption rate of piperazine (>1143.8 μmol h–1) was much higher than the formation rate of formaldehyde produced by photocatalytic dehydrogenation of methanol (35.3 μmol h–1) over 1.0Pd/TiO2-P, indicating that the condensation that occurred to produce C was not the rate-determining step for the N-methylation of piperazine. In addition, we compared the condensation of piperazine with formaldehyde in the coexistence of N-methylpiperazine A (Table S3). The conversion of piperazine (79.8%) was higher than that of A (18.8%), indicating that piperazine was more readily condensed with formaldehyde to form C and subsequently hydrogenated to A. Obviously, piperazine was easily condensed with HCHO, which could be ascribed to the formation of hydrogen bond between the N-H of piperazine and the C=O of HCHO (N-H···O=C). The H atom of N-H acted as a hydrogen bond donor and the O atom of C=O acted as a hydrogen bond acceptor, which helped activate the carbonyl group during the nucleophilic attack of the other N atom of piperazine to the carbonyl group of HCHO (Scheme S1) [35,36]. This phenomenon explained why A was the main product during the N-methylation of piperazine. Hydrogenation of enamine C as the final step in N-methylation was explored with molecular hydrogen. As shown in Fig. 7 , the hydrogenation reaction did not occur without Pd in the reaction system. The 1.0Pd/TiO2-P and 1.0Pd/TiO2-C with a higher proportion of Pd0 species facilitated the hydrogenation process from C to A to achieve better selectivity of A compared with that of 1.0Pd/TiO2-H [37,38]. With increasing Pd content, more C was hydrogenated to A. So, the selectivity to A continued to increase in the N-methylation of piperazine (Fig. S8). The selectivity of A in the N-methylation of piperazine was closely related to the hydrogenation activity of C over Pd/TiO2 catalysts. After the disassembly analysis of the three steps of N-methylation of piperazine, 1.0Pd/TiO2-P prepared via photodeposition showed the best activity due to its better simultaneous performance of photocatalytic methanol dehydrogenation and intermediate hydrogenation. Moreover, the consumption rate of C for 1.0Pd/TiO2-P (468.0 μmol h–1) was much higher than the formation rate of formaldehyde (35.3 μmol h–1), suggesting that the photocatalytic dehydrogenation of methanol was the slowest step in the N-methylation of piperazine. To obtain more insight into the structure-activity relationship, UV–vis and PL spectra were carried out over 1.0Pd/TiO2 catalysts and bare TiO2 support, respectively, as shown in Fig. 8 . Bare TiO2 only showed absorption at a wavelength below 390 nm and the 1.0Pd/TiO2 catalysts presented an enhanced absorption of visible light (Fig. 8 a) [39]. The band gaps of TiO2 and 1.0Pd/TiO2 catalysts were estimated from the Tauc curves and varied in the range of 3.27–3.31 eV, indicating that the loading of Pd did not change the band gap of TiO2. The transfer and separation of photogenerated charge carriers were identified by PL spectra (Fig. 8 b). The presence of Pd species remarkably reduced PL intensity compared with TiO2, indicating that the recombination of h+–e– pairs was effectively suppressed over 1.0Pd/TiO2 catalysts [40]. Moreover, 1.0Pd/TiO2-P exhibited lower PL intensity among 1.0Pd/TiO2 catalysts, corresponding to higher electron transfer rate and separation efficiency of photogenerated h+–e– pairs. This phenomenon accounted for its better photocatalytic activity. The in situ ESR was used to detect the radicals generated during the reaction. The radical signal attributed to hydroxymethyl radical (·CH2OH) was detected for both methanol and methanol/piperazine mixtures under radiation (Fig. 9 a) [41]. The result indicated the activation of α-C–H bond during the dehydrogenation of CH3OH by holes. The hydroxymethyl radical should be an intermediate for the formation of formaldehyde. Studies on the different steps of N-methylation suggested that the overall N-methylation process was limited by the dehydrogenation step of methanol. To gain more insight into this step, kinetic isotope effect (KIE) was explored using isotopic substitution reagents (CH3OD and CD3OH). In general, the hydrogen atom (H) replacement by its isotope deuterium (D) is known as the hydrogen isotope effect. The hydrogen isotope effect can be classified into primary hydrogen kinetic isotope effect (PHKIE) and secondary hydrogen kinetic isotope effect (SHKIE) [42,43]. In PHKIE, the isotopically substituted hydrogen is broken, whereas in SHKIE, the isotopic substitution is remote from the breaking of the bond. In Fig. 9 b, the KIE for CH3OH/CH3OD in methanol dehydrogenation was 0.71, which belonged to SHKIE, suggesting that the cleavage of O–H bond was not the rate-determining step. The KIE for CH3OH/CD3OH in methanol was 2.29, which belonged to PHKIE. In addition, this value was close to that of the KIE for N-methylation (0.75 for CH3OH/CH3OD and 2.39 for CH3OH/CD3OH in Fig. 9 c), indicating that the α-C–H bond cleavage of methanol was the rate-determining step for the overall N-methylation reaction over 1.0Pd/TiO2-P [44]. 3.4 Recycling test and substrate scope To investigate the catalyst stability, a reusability experiment of 1.0Pd/TiO2-P catalyst for N-methylation of piperazine to A was evaluated. The results are plotted in Fig. 10 . After four cycles, the conversion of piperazine decreased slightly from 25.9% to 23.7% with minimal change in the selectivity of A. As shown in Figs. S9 and S10, the sizes of Pd NPs in used 1.0Pd/TiO2-P increased slightly from 2.5 nm to 2.8 nm, and the proportion of Pd0 species decreased from 68.5% to 63.4%. The structure of 1.0Pd/TiO2-P during the photocatalytic reactions can be stable. In addition, the substrate scope of reactions was examined for the N-alkylation of N-heterocyclic compounds with different alcohols (Table 2 ). When ethanol was used, the N-alkylation activity was similar to that of methanol. When the longer-chained propanol was used, the conversion of piperazine decreased to 67.5%. The N-alkylation of different N-heterocyclic compounds and methanol was implemented with high selectivity for the N-alkylated products. The 1.0Pd/TiO2-P can be effectively used for the synthesis of N-alkylated products from N-heterocyclic compounds. Table S4 compares the N-alkylation results of piperazine with alcohols on catalyst 1.0Pd/TiO2-P, and those of different amines with alcohols on various catalysts. Clearly, the N-alkylation of amines with alcohols using thermal catalysis requires high temperature and alkaline additives (entries 1–4) [45–48]. By contrast, our results indicate that N-alkylation of piperazine with lower alcohols (methanol, ethanol, and propanol) by photocatalysis can afford the desired products with good yield under mild conditions without using additives and the results are comparable with the photocatalytic N-alkylation of other amines with alcohols (entries 5–10) [13,49,50]. 3.5 Proposed reaction mechanism Based on above observations, we proposed the photo-driven N-methylation of piperazine with methanol over Pd/TiO2 as shown in Scheme 2 . Methanol was first oxidized to hydroxymethyl radical (·CH2OH) and H+ by photogenerated holes (①) and then further dehydrogenated to HCHO (②), formed H+ transferred to bond with Pd nanoparticles that capture photogenerated electrons to form Pd-H species. Enamine was formed through the rapid condensation between piperazine and in situ generated HCHO (③). Enamine was further hydrogenated to N-alkyl piperazine with Pd-H species (④). 4 Conclusions We demonstrated the light-driven N-alkylation of piperazine to construct C–N bond over Pd-modified semiconductor nanophotocatalyst Pd/TiO2-P by photodeposition. The optimized 1.0Pd/TiO2-P catalyst with 2.5 ± 0.5 nm average Pd NPs containing high proportion of metallic Pd0 species exhibited better activity compared with catalysts obtained by chemical reduction using NaBH4 (1.0Pd/TiO2-C) or reduction by H2 (1.0Pd/TiO2-H). The reaction followed a tandem process, and the photocatalytic dehydrogenation of methanol was the slowest step. This finding was obtained by comparing the rates of different reaction steps in the tandem N-alkylation reaction. For the N-methylation of piperazine, the α-C–H cleavage of methanol to form hydroxymethyl radical (·CH2OH) was the rate-determining step in the overall N-methylation reaction over ESR and isotopic experiments. This study provided an efficient way to realize a highly efficient N-alkylation of N-heterocyclic compounds by successful coupling of semiconductor-based photocatalyst with Pd NPs for hydrogenation. This study also highlighted the rational configuration of multifunctional photocatalysts for light induce value-added organic synthesis. coredata.dc:description: N-alkylated piperazines can be synthesized by the thermal catalytic alkylation of piperazine with alkyl halides or alcohols in the presence of supported metal catalysts. However, these processes either discharge large amounts of waste or require harsh conditions. Here, we report the results of N-alkylation of piperazine with lower alcohols (methanol, ethanol, and propanol) without external hydrogen addition at room temperature in the presence of a TiO2-supported Pd catalyst (Pd/TiO2-P) prepared by photodeposition method. Compared with the catalysts prepared by the conventional chemical reduction or hydrogen reduction, the Pd/TiO2-P catalyst showed the highest conversion of piperazine and the best selectivity to N-alkypiperazines. The mechanistic studies indicated that this phenomenon occurs via tandem photocatalytic reactions involving alcohol dehydrgenation to aldehyde, aldehyde condensation with piperazine to enamine, and enamine hydrogenation to N-alkylated piperazines. Considering the experimental results of methanol isotope kinetics, the α-C–H cleavage of methanol to form hydroxymethyl radical (·CH2OH) was proven to be the rate-determining step in the N-alkylation reaction of piperazine with low carbon alcohols. The characterization and control experiments revealed that the size of Pd nanoparticles and the valence of Pd species were vital to the reaction. The Pd/TiO2-P catalyst with an average of 2.5 ± 0.5 nm Pd particles and approximately 68% Pd0 species on surfaces presented the highest activity for the photocatalytic tandem reactions of methanol dehydrogenation and enamine hydrogenation.
coredata.dc:title: Mechanistic insight into the photocatalytic N-alkylation of piperazine with alcohols over TiO2 supported Pd catalysts
